%c[0,153,255,255]Artefact degradation%c[0,140,140,140] causes artefact abilities and bonuses to degrade when activated.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
With this feature enabled having the best artefacts is no-longer the end of the line for artefact hunters.
 
Artefacts will become weaker the more they are used, promoting their further hunting and accumulation, instead of becoming just a quick source of income.
 
This feature can be toggled from the game options menu and is disabled by default.

%c[0,153,255,255]Azazel mode%c[0,140,140,140] allows you to continue playing as another character after death.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
In Azazel mode death is not the end - upon the demise of your character you will posses the body of a random stalker who was previously controlled by the AI.
 
Should you have companions at the time of your death, they will be given priority and you will continue playing as one of them instead.
 
This mode can only be enabled from the character creation screen.
 
 
%c[0,204,0,51]• %c[0,140,140,140]Not compatible with Story mode.
 
%c[0,204,0,51]• %c[0,140,140,140]Miracle Machine and Brain Scorcher are turned off in Azazel mode.

%c[0,153,255,255]Delayed repairs%c[0,140,140,140] allows technicians to retain your equipment.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
With this feature enabled, broken weapons, outfits, and other items which you bring to a technician will be kept in their possession until they have completed all repairs.
 
After handing over your items you can speak with the technician again to ask whether they are ready for pick-up, to which they will either return them or tell you how much time they still require.
 
This adds a somewhat realistic enhancement to the traditional repair system, suitable if you are seeking a harder experience, as it will no-longer work instantaneously and instead emphasise the use of gunsmith and sewing kits.
 
This feature can be toggled from the game options menu and is disabled by default.

%c[0,153,255,255]Dynamic news%c[0,140,140,140] allows stalkers to report on their experiences in the Zone.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
Stalkers will comment on events that they have seen or heard near their location, or on their current activities, using the PDA communications network.
 
These events and activities can range from something as mundane as complaining about the price of goods sold by a trader, to requesting help from faction allies when under attack.
 
Many other features also tie into the system; stalkers may comment on suspicious activity when you are hunting a bounty, giving you an idea where your target is, or may mention if somebody has a job available.
 
This feature can be toggled from the game options menu and is enabled by default.

%c[0,153,255,255]Extended HUD%c[0,140,140,140] allows the display of additional on-screen information.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
With this feature enabled brief companion information and a miniaturised version of the artefact belt are made visible on the heads-up display.
 
This feature can be toggled from the UI/HUD options menu and is disabled by default.

%c[0,153,255,255]Hardcore AI%c[0,140,140,140] aim increases AI aim predictability and decreases reaction times.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
With this feature enabled it becomes harder for you to avoid being hit whilst strafing and sprinting, with the use of cover becoming much more essential to your long-term survival.
 
This feature can be toggled from the game options menu and is disabled by default.

%c[0,153,255,255]Helicopter patrols%c[0,140,140,140] enables factions the use of air support to defend strategic areas.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
Factions who have friendly aircraft patrolling in the area will be able to call on them for support in attacking, or defending from, enemy stalkers (including you) and mutants.
 
Despite their intimidating appearance they can be easily taken down after receiving a light amount of damage to the tail rotor.
 
This feature can be toggled from the game options menu and is enabled by default.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Locations%c[0,140,140,140]
 
• Agroprom
• Cordon
• Darkscape
• Great Swamp
• Limansk

%c[0,153,255,255]Ironman mode%c[0,140,140,140] adds an indirect layer of difficulty to gameplay, whereby all of your saved games for a character are deleted upon their death.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
Should Azazel mode be enabled at the same time you will be allowed to continue playing as whoever you switched to, but saves made as your deceased character will be deleted as per usual.
 
Note that all saves in an ironman mode playthrough are tagged with a unique identifier so the game can distinguish between them, making it impossible for unrelated saves to be deleted by mistake.
 
This mode can only be enabled from the character creation screen.

%c[0,153,255,255]Online exclusion%c[0,140,140,140] creates a no-spawn zone around your character.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
As you explore near the edges of levels and their entry/exit points you could be attacked by enemies arriving from other levels. With online exclusion enabled these spawns are delayed until you are safely out of the way.
 
It should be noted that this system revolves entirely around you; any enemies already at a location whilst you are changing levels will not be de-spawned upon your arrival.
 
This feature can be adjusted from the game options menu and is set to 75 by default.

%c[0,153,255,255]Population factors%c[0,140,140,140] modify the number of stalkers and mutants found in the Zone.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
Stalker and mutant population factors can be adjusted independently from one another, allowing you to decide how wild or settled the Zone should be without the need to modify any of the game's files.
 
It should be noted that the effect is greatest when starting a new character, as if the factors are changed during a playthrough in progress, they will only be realised as stalkers and/or mutants die and then respawn in greater or smaller numbers.
 
These features can be adjusted from the game options menu.

%c[0,153,255,255]Portrait by outfit%c[0,140,140,140] changes your portrait based on your current outfit.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
With this feature enabled, every time you equip or unequip an outfit (not including headgear) your character's portrait will be updated to reflect this, mimicking how portraits for the AI match with how they look.
 
This feature can be toggled from the gameplay options menu and is disabled by default.

%c[0,153,255,255]Radio music%c[0,140,140,140] allows for custom music tracks to be played at certain locations.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
Certain relaxed areas within the Zone have radios installed nearby, with each playing a selection of musical tracks to keep stalkers entertained.
 
This feature can be toggled from the game options menu and is enabled by default.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Locations%c[0,140,140,140]
 
• Agroprom - Military base
• Cordon - Sidorovich's bunker
• Great Swamp - Clear Sky base
• Dark Valley - Bandit base
• Rostok - 100 Rads
• Red Forest - Forester's tower

%c[0,153,255,255]Rank%c[0,140,140,140] is a score system based on what a stalker has accomplished in the Zone.
 
Actions which you perform throughout your playthrough are recorded and each grant a varying number of points depending on the action in question.
 
As you accumulate more and more points your rank will gradually change as you pass through every milestone, with each requiring an additional 1000 points on top of the requirements of its predecessor.
 
Most of these actions are logged in the statistics tab of the PDA, which also contains an in-game leaderboard that keeps track of the current top-100 highest ranking stalkers.
 
There are currently eight total ranks available:
 
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Rookie (0)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Trainee (1000) (+1000)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Experienced (3000) (+2000)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Professional (6000) (+3000)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Veteran (10000) (+4000)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Expert (15000) (+5000)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Master (21000) (+6000)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Legend (28000) (+7000)

%c[0,153,255,255]Reputation%c[0,140,140,140] is a representation of how a stalker interacts with others.
 
Reputation is similar to rank but differs in that it isn't quite so linear - being able to both increase and decrease - and that it is based on your interactions with other stalkers rather than the environment.
 
The easiest ways to increase reputation are by completing tasks, providing first-aid, and killing your faction's enemies, whilst inversely the easiest ways to lose it are by cancelling or failing tasks, and killing neutral or friendly stalkers.
 
It should be noted that reputation is not to be confused with goodwill, which handles all stalker and faction relations. Reputation is largely an immersion-focused feature for the benefit of the player.
 
There are currently nine total reputations available:
 
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Terrible (-2000) (-500)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Dreary (-1500) (-500)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Awful (-1000) (-500)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Bad (-500) (-500)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Neutral (0)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Good (500) (+500)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Great (1000) (+500)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Brilliant (1500) (+500)
%c[0,100,100,255]• %c[0,140,140,140]Excellent (2000) (+500)

%c[0,153,255,255]Sleep deprivation%c[0,140,140,140] allows time and the use of consumables to fatigue your character.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
Throughout the Zone you will find many beds and sleeping bags, normally they are only used to allow the you to skip time by sleeping, however with this feature enabled they become an essential part of gameplay.
 
As time passes your character will slowly begin to feel tired, with the screen beginning to blur and shake. These effects will proceed to get worse until you find a suitable place to rest or the effects of sleep deprivation cause you to collapse from exhaustion.
 
Tiredness can be accelerated through consuming items such as medical kits and vodka, and negated with those such as high-caffeine energy drinks - however using too many will leave you unable to rest until their effects wear off.
 
This feature can be toggled from the game options menu and is disabled by default.

%c[0,153,255,255]Story mode%c[0,140,140,140] enables a non-linear story based on the events of Shadow of Chernobyl.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
With this mode enabled you start the game with the 'Mysteries of the Zone' storyline, and the tasks of disabling both the Brain Scorcher and the Miracle Machine.
 
To begin the story you will need to find an important individual hiding somewhere within the Zone, who after a brief dialogue will provide you with multiple tasks which can be completed in any order.
 
This mode can only be enabled from the character creation screen.

%c[0,153,255,255]Survival mode%c[0,140,140,140] turns the Zone into a hunting ground - where you are the prey.
 
%c[0,0,255,30]Information%c[0,140,140,140]
 
With this mode enabled all spawns are replaced with zombified stalkers and mutants, who will slowly stumble towards your location in an attempt to kill you.
 
Exclusive to this gameplay mode are zombies themselves, the last devolution of zombified stalkers who have lost the ability to operate mechanical devices such as firearms.
 
Only a few traders and stalker squads can be found, meaning you will have to survive off of what you can scavenge in the world.
 
This mode can only be enabled from the character creation screen.
